text: now can use core vrtiltiy functions collect, reproject align (warp) data using vrt_compute() create single raster file VRT. Note set set important environment variables vrt_collect allow access Digital Earth Africa data S3 bucket.

title: EOPF Sentinel-2 Level-2A
text: example demonstrates standard workflow discovering filtering satellite imagery STAC (SpatioTemporal Asset Catalog) API. ’ll query EOPF STAC collection apply filters obtain specific datasets need. process involves: 1. Querying STAC collection available imagery 2. Filtering cloud coverage ensure data quality 3. Applying coverage filters guarantee sufficient spatial overlap example, ’re targeting bounding box around Copenhagen, Denmark, using stac_coverage_filter() ensure retrieve images adequate coverage area interest.
code: library(vrtility)  bbox <- gdalraster::bbox_from_wkt(   wkt = "POINT (12.56 55.67)",   extend_x = 0.3,   extend_y = 0.2 )  te <- bbox_to_projected(bbox) trs <- attr(te, "wkt")  eopf_s2 <- stac_query(   bbox = bbox,   stac_source = "https://stac.core.eopf.eodc.eu/",   collection = "sentinel-2-l2a",   start_date = "2025-05-01",   end_date = "2025-07-30" )  eopf_filter <- rstac::assets_select(   eopf_s2,   asset_names = c("B02_10m", "B03_10m", "B04_10m", "B08_10m") ) |>   stac_cloud_filter(max_cloud_cover = 30) |>   stac_coverage_filter(bbox, min_coverage = 0.5)

title: EOPF Sentinel-2 Level-2A
text: virtually warp images download disk using multiple processes within isolated set mirai daemons. Note call mirai::daemons() within () function ensure daemons properly cleaned use. Critically, must specify driver = "EOPFZARR" argument vrt_collect() GDAL , default, attempt read files using built-Zarr driver, fully support EOPF-Zarr format. Since want continue processing image set, use recollect = TRUE argument ensure new VRT collection returned rather file paths.
code: with(mirai::daemons(10), {   eopf_s2_chgn <- vrt_collect(     eopf_filter,     vsi_prefix = "/vsicurl/",     driver = "EOPFZARR"   ) |>     vrt_warp(       t_srs = trs,       te = te,       tr = c(10, 10)     ) |>     vrt_compute(       engine = "gdalraster",       recollect = TRUE     ) })

title: EOPF Sentinel-2 Level-2A
text: generate OmniCloudMask image VRT collection using red, green, NIR bands. cloud mask identifies pixels affected clouds, cloud shadows, atmospheric interference. apply mask filter low-quality pixels compute results disk. Note use recollect = TRUE return new VRT collection references newly created cloud-masked GeoTIFF files, allowing us continue working data virtualized format subsequent processing steps.
code: eopf_s2_mask <- eopf_s2_chgn |>   vrt_create_mask(     inbands = c(red = 3, green = 2, nir = 4),     maskfun = create_omnicloudmask()   ) |>   vrt_set_maskfun(     mask_band = "omnicloudmask",     mask_values = 1:3   ) |>   vrt_compute(     engine = "warp",     recollect = TRUE   )  purrr::walk(   seq_len(eopf_s2_mask$n_items),   ~ plot(eopf_s2_mask, item = .x, c(3, 2, 1), na_col = "#ffa928") )

title: EOPF Sentinel-2 Level-2A
text: generate geometric median composite cloud-masked images using multiband_reduce() geomedian() function. geometric median robust statistical method effectively reduces noise preserves spectral characteristics minimizing influence outliers residual cloud contamination. use mirai::daemons() parallelize computation across multiple cores, significantly improving processing speed computationally intensive operation.
code: with(mirai::daemons(10), {   eopf_s2_median <- multiband_reduce(     eopf_s2_mask,     reduce_fun = geomedian(),     outfile = fs::file_temp(ext = ".tif"),     recollect = TRUE   ) })  plot(   eopf_s2_median,   c(3, 2, 1),   na_col = "#ffa928" )

title: EOPF Sentinel-2 Level-2A
text: Spectral indices essential tools remote sensing extracting meaningful information multi-band imagery. Common indices like NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index), EVI (Enhanced Vegetation Index), others help identify vegetation health, water content, surface characteristics. vrtility package provides vrt_derived_block() efficient creation derived bands. function uses R’s intuitive formula syntax define band calculations, automatically translated muparser expressions executed using VRT pixel functions. approach provides memory-efficient computation without requiring intermediate file storage. example, ’ll calculate several useful indices visualize results:
code: exptest <- vrt_derived_block(   eopf_s2_median,   ndvi ~ (B08_10m - B04_10m) / (B08_10m + B04_10m),   ndti ~ (B04_10m - B03_10m) / (B04_10m + B03_10m),   evi ~ 2.5 * (B08_10m - B04_10m) / (B08_10m + 6 * B04_10m - 7.5 * B02_10m + 1),   vgnirbi ~ (B03_10m - B08_10m) / (B03_10m + B08_10m) )  print(exptest, pixfun = TRUE) #> → <VRT Block> #> VRT XML: [hidden] #>   run print(x, xml = TRUE) to view #> Pixel Function: #> ndvi ~ ((B08_10m * 0.0001) - (B04_10m * 0.0001))/((B08_10m * 0.0001) + (B04_10m * 0.0001))                                         #> ndti ~ ((B04_10m * 0.0001) - (B03_10m * 0.0001))/((B04_10m * 0.0001) + (B03_10m * 0.0001))                                         #> evi ~ 2.5 * ((B08_10m * 0.0001) - (B04_10m * 0.0001))/((B08_10m * 0.0001) + 6 * (B04_10m * 0.0001) - 7.5 * (B02_10m * 0.0001) + 1) #> vgnirbi ~ ((B03_10m * 0.0001) - (B08_10m * 0.0001))/((B03_10m * 0.0001) + (B08_10m * 0.0001)) #>  #>  #>  VRT SRS:  #> PROJCS["unknown",GEOGCS["unknown",DATUM["Unknown based on WGS 84 ellipsoid",SPHEROID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,AUTHORITY["EPSG","7030"]]],PRIMEM["Greenwich",0],UNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433,AUTHORITY["EPSG","9122"]]],PROJECTION["Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area"],PARAMETER["latitude_of_center",55.67],PARAMETER["longitude_of_center",12.56],PARAMETER["false_easting",0],PARAMETER["false_northing",0],UNIT["metre",1],AXIS["Easting",EAST],AXIS["Northing",NORTH]] #> Bounding Box: -18980 -22270 18980 22310 #> Pixel res: 10, 10 #> Assets: ndvi, ndti, evi, vgnirbi #> No Data Value(s): NaN, NaN, NaN, NaN #> Date Time: 2025-06-21 UTC  x <- vrt_compute(   exptest,   outfile = fs::file_temp(ext = ".tif") )   purrr::walk(   1:4,   ~ plot_raster_src(     x,     band = .x,     minmax_def = if (.x == 3) c(-1, 1) else NULL,     col = grDevices::hcl.colors(10, "Inferno")   ) )

what: Step 4: Calculate NDVI and Apply Temporal Filtering
title: Creating NDVI Time Series from HLS Data
text: Set NDVI calculation using vrt_derived_block() function automatically restructures data sets forumla VRT pixel function using muparser expressions. computed call singleband_m2m(), NDVI values temporally filtered using Hampel filter reduce noise residual clouds sensor artifacts: Hampel filtering: Hampel filter identifies outliers pixel’s time series computing median absolute deviation (MAD) within sliding window neighboring time steps. pixel time t, examines window [t-k … t+k] flags values deviate t0 x MAD local median. Window size (k=3): pixel compared 7 time steps (3 , current, 3 ) Threshold (t0=0): value differing local median flagged outlier (equivalent applying pure median filter). Setting t0=3 allow values within 3 MAD units median (Pearson’s rule normal data), making filter forgiving. Imputation (impute_na=TRUE): Outliers replaced last valid (non-outlier, non-NA) value earlier time series, effectively carrying forward recent “good” observation particularly effective removing clouds atmospheric artifacts Fmask missed, appear sharp deviations local temporal pattern.
code: tex_ndvi <- tex_s2_collect |>   # Calculate NDVI: (NIR - Red) / (NIR + Red)   vrt_derived_block(     ndvi ~ (B08 - B04) / (B08 + B04)   ) |>   # Apply Hampel filter to detect and replace outliers   # This helps remove residual cloud contamination and sensor noise   singleband_m2m(     m2m_fun = hampel_filter(       k = 3L, # Window size: 3 images before and after       t0 = 0, # Threshold: 0 standard deviations (aggressive filtering)       impute_na = TRUE # Replace no data with previous valid value     ),     recollect = TRUE # Rebuild VRT after filtering   )
